5EF4033A024E435E9BA0A600DAD407E0.description: Recognize a line of symmetry in a figure.

28ACC74250C84451821B14C755E7564C.description:
Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be
folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.

55C339F998D846DFA7456EE8BCED01F4.description: Categorize angles as right, acute, or obtuse.

18593CA8D7934C4C8F210146A0804431.description: Classify two-dimensional shapes based on attributes (number of angles).

24E8BF2D8D58488FBEDDB72F621D95A8.description:
Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the
presence or absence of angles of a specified size (e.g., understand right triangles as a category, and identify right
triangles).

D464382D607E488A87F6E631F84293BD.description: Recognize parallel and perpendicular lines within the context of two-dimensional figures.¬†

BA3242AC21D645788A7893D2AC424D73.description: Recognize an angle in two-dimensional figures.

AE0BA2EDFE644E46A3AEEB6E73365669.description: Recognize perpendicular and parallel lines in two-dimensional figure.

1403E393ED3C4588832E03A993B874BD.description: Recognize a point, line and line segment, rays in two-dimensional figures.¬†

5F5C2399538742FA89B9AEDFCF4BBC45.description:
Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify
these in two-dimensional figures.¬†

49B6418B97FB4C6F9A418B007CE719C1.description:
Draw and identify lines and
angles, and classify shapes
by properties of their lines
and angles.

5132EC66EAFC48BDB1D2B757B9A92B6C.description: No CCCs developed for this standard.

7C7D858EEF024C0FA313BFB77A6A1214.description:
Understand angle measures as additive. (When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle
measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts.) Solve addition and subtraction problems to
find unknown angles on a diagram within mathematical problems as well as problems in real-world contexts.

40FC4F3F55CC43F5A8C9E62B5CA5992E.description: Measure right angles using a tool (e.g., angle ruler, protractor).

1866D8F1917E47CA91DBDF2793BBF220.description: Select appropriate tool for measurement: mass, length, angles.

F6F13D9104BF4FB9AF53EDEAFA72A6A3.description: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.

F39837DCFAC5496D99829BE77AE71E27.description: No CCCs developed for this standard.

164B9B8C69574CC9AE8436E1DB0489E6.description:
Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and
understand concepts of angle measurement:
a. An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of the rays, by
considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two rays intersect the circle. An
angle that turns through 1/360 of a circle is called a ‚Äúone-degree angle,‚Äù and can be used to measure
angles.
b. An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.

B8888F66DD6D4038943EC9E04D15E3AB.description:
Geometric measurement:
Understand concepts of
angle and measure angles.

B61615EBAF6C408D9FD2D2FBDA664FF3.description: No CCCs developed for this standard.

C62564964F974F5687DDB1AEBEB496CB.description:
Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems
involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.¬†

C983CB9FA8F045CEB7F2D71780DA67BD.description: Apply the formulas for area and perimeter to solve real world problems.

15E42CA551E7490AABF2B52D6230B3F3.description:
Solve word problems using perimeter and area where changes occur to the dimensions of
a figure.

DA1B3520750D4233869B46ABD11246DC.description:
Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in mathematical problems and problems in real-world
contexts including problems with unknown side lengths. See Table 2.

26A3DF7F0EAF48B1B8C87FAFBBA9F212.description:
Solve word problems using perimeter and area where changes occur to the dimensions
of a figure.

5964BB8B0FF044D28DD357F24C28202B.description:
Use the four operations to solve word problems and problems in real-world context involving distances, intervals
of time (hr, min, sec), liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including decimals and problems involving
fractions with like denominators, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in
terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using a variety of representations, including number
lines that feature a measurement scale.

AAEA1BDA15654CB19F2697C8A48A71EC.description: Select appropriate units for measurement: mass, length, angles.

888756F7BFAF464F83086F6C91C6CC12.description: Complete a conversion table for length and mass within a single system.

ADAF838739354AEE814558DC061880DC.description:
Identify the appropriate units of measurement for different purposes in a real life context
(e.g., measure a wall using feet, not inches).

22102A863216490EBCF9229A77BA90FC.description:
Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units which could include km, m, cm; kg, g; lb, oz.;
l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a
smaller unit and in a smaller unit in terms of a larger unit. For example, know that 1 ft is 12 times as long as 1 in.
Express the length of a 4 ft snake as 48 in. Generate a conversion table for feet and inches listing the number
pairs (1,12), 2,24), (3,36).

8D9E2D01736F4121BC5949105C6BE1AE.description:
Solve problems involving
measurement and
conversion of measurements
from a larger unit to a
smaller unit.

3F7A557385E740B495F33E7EFD763679.description: Compare two decimals to the hundredths place with a value of less than 1.¬†

E5DCF917C5E74C5F9367C7484C21F344.description: Compare two decimals to the tenths place with a value of less than 1.¬†

6D2DE5606D354808849CEA69A6F02FA3.description: Use =, <, or > to compare 2 decimals (decimals in multiples of .10).

1B5317BD923A4C65A1B3D1417E1FA53C.description:
Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Understand that comparisons are valid only
when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <.

5F2B38927A554F2080BE0D7F2BD44A31.description: Rewrite a decimal as a fraction.¬†

2EBDD00EB51542C697B443E8C10A3710.description: Rewrite a fraction as a decimal.

96DED9909E7546508E7EFCB84DC7B170.description: Read, write or select decimals to the hundredths place.

91F2CB4DF01F49A98EC2F604801DD264.description: Read, write or select decimals to the tenths place

FA0F3EE29FB8453E866C1DD03E046CCB.description: Match a fraction with a denominator of 10 or 100 as a decimal (5/10 = .5).

091017CBE43B46E0B6317C7015E2F276.description: Identify the equivalent decimal for a fraction

F8FCB2CA9CC64800AE59EEF18AF568A8.description:
Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 (tenths) or 100 (hundredths), and locate these decimals
on a number line.¬†

03AECF9C3C974A9BBFA3D34631248080.description: Find the equivalent decimal for a given fraction.¬†

4F205EF67129498A8C6D160118B2A79A.description:
Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique
to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 (tenths) and 100 (hundredths). For example, express 3/10
as 30/100, and 3/10 + 4/100 = 34/100. (Note: Students who can generate equivalent fractions can develop
strategies for adding fractions with unlike denominators in general. But addition and subtraction with unlike
denominators, in general, is not a requirement at this grade.)

A27C0C25AD724564B93DF57F7BE43C31.description:
Understand decimal
notation for fractions, and
compare decimal fractions.

1B363C78D0374BA7B814D743328026A6.description: No CCCs developed for these standards.

7B6A36B117E54258B3725C7417A158C0.description:
Build fractions from unit fractions.
a. Understand a fraction ùëéùëé
ùëèùëè as a multiple of a unit fraction 1
ùëèùëè
. In general, ùëéùëé
ùëèùëè
= a x
1
ùëèùëè .
b. Understand a multiple of ùëéùëé
ùëèùëè as a multiple of a unit fraction 1
ùëèùëè , and use this understanding to multiply a whole
number by a fraction. In general, n x ùëéùëé
ùëèùëè
 = ùëõùëõ ùë•ùë• ùëéùëé
ùëèùëè .
c. Solve word problems involving multiplication of a whole number by a fraction. For example, if each person at a
party will eat 3/8 of a pound of roast beef, and there will be 5 people at the party, how many pounds of roast beef
will be needed? Between what two whole numbers does your answer lie?

5A0318D1591B4EEDAEBD622A079D183A.description:
Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions with like
denominators (2, 3, 4, or 8).

A609803E08A543CC9814A219442E1D2B.description: Add and subtract fractions with like denominators (2,3,4, or 8) using representations.

4BB3F21804EE4E91B1A5C0BFF7DFF90E.description: Add and subtract fractions with like denominators of (2,3,4, or 8).

CCDE149EAE5247D3B1180A9F4FE4028E.description:
Using a representation, decompose a fraction into multiple copies of a unit fraction (e.g., ¬æ
= ¬º + ¬º + ¬º ).

B53B0B8CE0D64C2EAE300875A24BEFD2.description:
Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of unit fractions (1/b).
a. Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.
b. Decompose a fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in more than one way
(e.g., 3/8 = 1/8 + 1/8+1/8; 3/8 = 2/8 + 1/8; 2 1/8 = 1 + 1 + 1/8 + or 2 1/8 = 8/8 + 8/8 + 1/8).
c. Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators (e.g., by using properties of operations and the
relationship between addition and subtraction and/or by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent
fraction).
d. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having
like denominators.

A9522FDB763E4B528C5D62BF95C572DE.description:
Build fractions from unit
fractions by applying and
extending previous
understanding of operations
on whole numbers.

86F4DD95491848BF84768353379CC9D7.description: Compare up to 2 given fractions that have different denominators.

28434466F2CE4AD4858DEB01E016A87F.description: Use =, <, or > to compare 2 fractions (fractions with a denominator or 10 or less).

355D544B6DEE42C583081E84F88FEB22.description:
Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators (e.g., by creating common
denominators or numerators and by comparing to a benchmark fraction).
a. Understand that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same size whole.
b. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions.

31AA16036ED64F0DBA8872368675CB52.description:
Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n x a)/(n x b) by using visual fraction models, with attention
to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use
this principle to understand and generate equivalent fractions.

F32344DC2F104227B4EECAADCF73C63E.description:
Extend understanding of
fraction equivalence and
ordering.

7C1DA7CEB04D41638DE24F0BBE36A2DD.description:
Separate a group of objects into equal sets when given the number of sets to find the total
in each set with the total number less than 50.¬†

E1AFC113167E4C5C807931BDA12ACF77.description:
Demonstrate understanding of division by finding whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit
dividends and one-digit divisors.

44282A4E58294FA0A654940643B997C6.description: Solve a 2-digit by 1-digit multiplication problem using two different strategies.

A4D21CFA158041DA921ABE34F9DB7A8C.description:
Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers,
using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by
using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

C3E402DBB88644449E3E7CF59F743800.description: Solve multiplication problems up to two digits by one digit.

ECDFBA48D7D14472ADA8508466A2F0CE.description: Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using a standard algorithm.¬†

60E0F73C92F94521AA97CB75C03CF31C.description:
Use place value
understanding and
properties of operations to
perform multi-digit
arithmetic.¬†¬†

42F16DD7026948EC9FC2BB9DE57558A6.description: Use place value to round to any place (i.e., ones, tens, hundreds, thousands).

F1F625B1CC734E238471697A150948DF.description: Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.

E666784F71664D3495A526059FC4BA7F.description: Write or select the expanded form for a multi-digit number.

67D94A84A3BA4967B924490194BB2420.description: Compare multi-digit numbers using representations and numbers.¬†

5656B1AEEE47405E95B5E0B52A387D62.description:
Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form.
Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to
record the results of comparisons.

7FD325A8A6C74739B06B4AA6C0083E4E.description:
Compare the value of a number when it is represented in different place values of two 3
digit numbers.

1B779CEA56964A3C8FEEDE63C8EE63DB.description:
Apply concepts of place value, multiplication, and division to understand that in a multi-digit whole number, a
digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.

F53E5FEA72F74771908451DAA767E32F.description:
Generalize place value
understanding for multi-digit
whole numbers.¬†

AEE1039EFA7A4DCEA250610232E298A0.description: Number and Operations in Base Ten

0B3BB0230DB14584B40E1E50A621AAFA.description: No CCCs developed for this standard.

465581ABD1BA47C48EBC39E0C30D31DD.description:
When solving problems, assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation
strategies including rounding.¬†

41464CC15A6240118287743393EEF71E.description: Generate a pattern that follows the provided rule.

84CA4A85A82C46FC9BA0986A604475CC.description: Extend a numerical pattern when the rule is provided.

BF893A396D5443ACBF5BFC9C7B6A2AAE.description:
Generate a pattern when given a rule and word problem (I run 3 miles every day, how
many miles have I run in 3 days).¬†

20B831B0CD204C40B9443414B2E78DCC.description:
Generate a number pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not
explicit in the rule itself and explain the pattern informally (e.g., given the rule ‚Äúadd 3‚Äù and the starting number
1, generate terms in the resulting sequence and observe that the terms appear to alternate between odd and
even numbers).

CD3A3428E56E4EFBBEAC15BB89BA925E.description:
Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1 to 100 and understand that a whole number is a multiple
of each of its factors.

96A93856FC53411898D9EEF4F10B8629.description:
Gain familiarity with factors
and multiples.

2C7A761A9AA4457A814D5764698B5FF8.description:
Solve multistep word problems using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be
interpreted. Understand how the remainder is a fraction of the divisor. Represent these problems using
equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity.

8C5B9F418C254FC2A96AD04523128655.description:
Solve multiplicative comparisons with an unknown using up to 2-digit numbers with
information presented in a graph or word problem (e.g., an orange hat cost $3. A purple hat
cost 2 times as much. How much does the purple hat cost? [3 x 2 = p]).

041DD1823ECE44479D09A5D6D235429D.description:
Determine how many objects go into each group when given the total number of objects
and the number of groups where the number in each group or number of groups is not
greater than 10.

084C7AD7384B4D9E880A3ABBA7DD461D.description:
Multiply or divide within 1000 to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison (e.g., by using
drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing
multiplicative comparison from additive comparison). See Table 2.

2BD7774EA1C84425B4805ACAA41E673E.description: No CCCs developed for this standard.

6B737052ED13430F88BD193B014D2E69.description:
Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations. Interpret a multiplication
equation as a comparison (e.g., 35 is the number of objects in 5 groups, each containing 7 objects, and is also the
number of objects in 7 groups, each containing 5 objects).¬†

B45532371151469DA8F795939DC2D586.description:
Use the four operations with
whole numbers to solve
problems.
